title.narrative: (100% Envelope 1), Upgrading of expired shelter units (tents) to the dignified shelter solution and all other related infrastructures and facilities in Al Ajami Camp in Salqin Sub-district in Idleb governorate.

description.narrative:
The project aims to target Al Ajami Camp(CP002065) by providing and replacing 248 un-secured, un-protected, non-privacy, and un-dignified tents with 248 dignified shelter units (166Single-HUs, and 82Twin-HUs), for decent and saved lives for 252HHs (1,380Ind, 265M, 321W, 358B, 409G, 54PwDs) who are currently living in those tents. Both housing units' designs are classified as dignified, more sustainable, and made of sandwich panels for walls and roofs, PVC internal doors, and windows. Each unit is equipped with a toilet, bathroom, and kitchen, in addition to the final flooring layer through CFW program Selected Ajami due to: -Strong wind repeatedly uprooted the tents, and many families left the camp toward more-crowded camps in nearby communities. They appealed to provide them with shelter, so their families return as soon as possible -Urgent needs, replacing the worn-off tents with better-dignified shelter solutions, expanding the water and sewage networks, and lighting (Consultation Sessions Findings) -Ajami has all ingredients that qualify it to continue as an official camp with a capacity of more than 600 housing units, and a possibility to expand with public land available -Value of Money is increased in this site due to previously well-prepared infrastructures including sewage and water nets, graveled roads, fence, school, and mosque
Moreover, BINAA circulated individual discussions using Consultation Forms, surveyed 16 IDP sites, and introduced 11 different solutions for shelters with different characteristics "based on SNFI Dignified Shelter Guideline". (Attach_SA1-T06_Shelter Checklist) That 97% of residents had stated acceptance to such the module for: *Local availability of skills and materials *25m2 Inter-area *5m2 Covered living space per person (match SPHERE), including WASH facilities, and 2.5m minimum roof height to protect from weather *Low-cost design using the shared-walls partitions without any effect on privacy *Minimum 10-year lifespan *High protection against weather, fire, dust, wind, rain, snow, and insects *High privacy and security *Easy remove and reuse units by local skills The interlinked SNFI, WASH, and ERL activities are developed with the Clusters to ensure integration with ongoing and planned works SNFI: 1. Replacing 248 tents with the most preferred Shelter solution (option 11 as mentioned) *166 HHs of 6 members or fewer will be awarded Single units. *82 HHs of 7 members or more will be awarded Twin units. This is to keep the family together and to increase the "Value for Money" by decreasing the cost while building shared walls. The HHs are counted, coded, and distributed to the units as per (Attach_SA1-N06_BNFs Database) 2.Constructing 1bath, 1WC, and 1kitchen for units 3.Constructing special facilities for HHs with PwDs 4.Road light rehabilitation 5.Constructing rain drainage system.6.Paving pathways with stones.7.Paving special ramps and entrances for PwDs, all are integrated with ERL CFW 8.Camp lighting WASH 1)Extending and maintaining the Sewage and Water Networks to connect the Units' WASH facilities 2)Installing a 500-liter tank for each unit 3)Construct a high water tank, 80m3 4)Equipping the existed bore-well with (Solar-power, Electrical Inverter to connect public network, 200-KVA generator currently available, so saving money) 5)Providing additional 65 Trash containers (100-liter) 6)Supporting operation costs and WASH services (septic tank desludging, water tracking, and waste removal) for 3-months during maintaining the public networks 7)Hygiene awareness ERL Integrate 162CFW workers in: 1.Flooring works for the units 2.Paving the rain drainage system with stones 3.Paving the pathways with stones 4.Paving special ramps and pathways for PwDs 5.Cleaning the sewage and rain drainage channels 6.Planting trees Ultimately, BINAA will coordinate with the Clusters, and local councils to connect the camp to the nearby public electricity network
